page.title: 20CHANGES:LEASINGHAM (PART3)
page.content:
A "local" said that he felt R.A.F. Cranwell had been a good thing for Leasingham,as there was little other local employment in the 1950's apart from a few farming jobs.He said that the village had become rather impersonal as it had grown:"Before," he said,"everyone knew everyone else." The general feeling of the villagers was that the movement of population didn't harm the community.
THIS CONTRIBUTION TO THE "DOMESDAY PROJECT" WAS COMPILED BY CLASS 5 AT LEASINGHAM (C.E.) CONTROLLED PRIMARY SCHOOL, LEASINGHAM, SLEAFORD, LINCS., WITH HELP FROM THEIR CLASS TEACHER AND MEMBERS OF THE LOCAL COMMUNITY.
